all-purpose flour.ingredientName: half bread flour + half cake flour
all-purpose flour.notes: For 1 cup AP flour, combine 1/2 cup bread flour and 1/2 cup cake flour.
For 1 cup AP flour, remove 2 Tbsp and replace with 2 Tbsp cornstarch.
For 1 cup AP flour, add 1 1/2 tsp baking powder + 1/2 tsp salt.

allspice.notes: For 1 tsp allspice, use 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 1/4 tsp ginger, 1/4 tsp cloves.
Alternatively, 3/4 tsp cinnamon, pinch of ground cloves, pinch of grated nutmeg.

apple cider vinegar.notes: Use equal amounts. Good for dressings and baking.

baking mix.notes: Use 1 cup pancake mix for 1 cup baking mix.

baking powder.notes: For 1 tsp baking powder, use 1/4 tsp baking soda + 1/2 tsp cream of tartar.
For 1 tsp baking powder, use 1/4 tsp baking soda + 1/2 cup buttermilk (reduce other liquid by 1/2 cup).
For 1 tsp, combine 1/2 tsp cream of tartar + 1/4 tsp baking soda. Sometimes a bit of cornstarch is added.

baking soda.notes: For 1 tsp baking soda, use ~3 or 4 tsp baking powder. May affect taste/texture.
For 1 tsp baking soda, use 1 tsp potassium bicarbonate + 1/3 tsp salt.

balsamic vinegar.notes: For 1 Tbsp balsamic vinegar, use 1 Tbsp white wine vinegar + 1/2 tsp sugar, brown sugar or honey.

basil.notes: Use about 1 tsp dried for 1 Tbsp fresh. Adjust to taste.
If using fresh, swap at a 1:1 ratio, though flavor will differ significantly.

beer.notes: Use equal amounts in batters or stews.
Use equal amounts; flavor changes, but adds savory note.

bread crumbs.notes: Use 1 cup cracker crumbs for 1 cup bread crumbs.
Use 1 cup for 1 cup bread crumbs.
Use 1 cup for 1 cup bread crumbs.
Adds a saltier taste and crunchy texture.

brown sugar.notes: For 1 cup brown sugar, use 1 cup white sugar + 1/4 cup molasses; reduce other liquid ~1/4 cup.
Use equal amount, though flavor is lighter.
Use ~1 1/4 cups for 1 cup brown sugar, but texture may differ.
Similar to brown sugar, though flavor/texture can vary slightly.

butter.notes: Use about half the amount as butter. Adds moisture; best in sweet baked goods.
Similar texture; slight green color. Works best in cakes, brownies.
Adds moisture and flavor. Good for quick breads, muffins.
Use equal amount; has a slight coconut flavor. Dairy-free.
Use equal amount. For salted recipes, adjust salt if margarine is salted.
Use equal amount for a creamy texture; may alter flavor slightly.
For 1 cup butter, use 1 cup shortening + 1/2 tsp salt (if butter was salted).
Use equal amount; clarified butter with a higher smoke point.
Approx. replacement for 1 cup butter. Check taste for salt content.

buttermilk.notes: For 1 cup buttermilk, add 1 Tbsp vinegar/lemon juice to milk, let stand 5 min.
Use equal amount. Thins texture if needed with a little water.
Use equal amount, possibly thin with water to match consistency.
Use equal amount; tangy flavor similar to buttermilk.

cake flour.notes: For 1 cup cake flour, measure 1 cup AP flour, remove 2 Tbsp and replace with 2 Tbsp cornstarch.

cardamom.notes: Use equal amount or slightly less; flavor differs but is warm and sweet.
Gives a pungent note similar to cardamom.

cayenne pepper.notes: Use about double the amount of flakes for the same heat level.

cheddar cheese.notes: Use equal amount; flavor is similar.
Melts well; flavor will be milder/sweeter.

chevre (goat cheese).notes: Use equal amount; flavor is less tangy.
Loosen mascarpone with a little yogurt to mimic goat cheese consistency.

chervil.notes: Use equal amount. Flavor is somewhat similar but less delicate.

chicken base.notes: Replace 1 Tbsp base with 1 cup homemade or canned broth; reduce other liquid by 1 cup.

chicken broth.ingredientName: water + soy sauce or bouillon cube
chicken broth.notes: Use 1 cup water plus 1 bouillon cube or 1 Tbsp soy sauce.

chili powder.notes: For 1 Tbsp chili powder, combine 1 tsp paprika, 1 tsp cumin, 1/2 tsp onion powder, 1/2 tsp garlic powder.

cilantro.notes: Use fresh 1:1, though flavor differs. Sometimes combined with basil.
Use fresh 1:1 for a sweet, aromatic twist.

coconut oil.notes: Use equal amount; flavor changes from coconut to buttery.
Use equal amount; less flavor in final dish.

condensed cream of mushroom soup.notes: Use equal amount. Flavor changes slightly.

corn starch.notes: Use 1:1 for sauces, gravies, or custards.
Use ~2 tsp for every 1 Tbsp cornstarch.
Use ~3 Tbsp flour for 1 Tbsp cornstarch.

corn syrup.notes: For 1 cup corn syrup, dissolve 1 cup sugar in 1/4 cup hot water.
Use equal amount; flavor changes slightly.

cream (half-and-half, light, heavy).notes: For 1 cup half-and-half, use ~7/8 cup milk + 1 Tbsp melted butter.
Use equal amount for cooking/baking. Not ideal for whipping.
For 1 cup light cream, use 3/4 cup milk + 3 Tbsp melted butter, or thicken with cornstarch.
Use equal amount for soups or sauces; flavor changes.

cream cheese.notes: Slightly lower fat; use equal amount.

cream cheese.ingredientName: pureed cottage cheese or ricotta + pinch of salt
cream cheese.notes: Blend until smooth; may curdle when heated.

cream of tartar.notes: For 1 tsp cream of tartar, use 2 tsp lemon juice or vinegar (may affect liquid balance).

creme fraiche.notes: Use equal amount. Flavor slightly tangier.
Combine 1 cup heavy cream + 1 Tbsp plain yogurt; let stand at room temp 6 hrs.
Use equal amount; thicker texture, tangier flavor.

dijon mustard.notes: For ~2 Tbsp Dijon, combine 1 Tbsp dry mustard, 1 Tbsp mayo, 1 tsp vinegar, pinch sugar.

egg.notes: Use ~50g (1/4 cup) for 1 egg. Adds sweetness and moisture.
Use ~3 Tbsp for 1 egg. Good binder in sweet recipes.
Use ~3 Tbsp for 1 egg. Adds moisture and slight flavor.
1 Tbsp seeds + 3 Tbsp water = 1 egg. Let sit to gel.
Liquid from canned chickpeas; whips similarly for meringues.
Acts as an egg replacement in muffins or pancakes.

egg whites.notes: Use ~2 Tbsp per egg white. Whips to foam; good for meringues.

evaporated milk.notes: Flavor is slightly different; adjust for sweetness/fat.
Use to achieve a thicker consistency.

fats for baking.notes: Use 1:1 for oil or butter; final texture moister, may be denser.

fish sauce.notes: Use less if salt content is high; lacks the pungent fishy note.

flour (bread).notes: For 1 cup bread flour, use 1 cup AP flour + 1 tsp vital wheat gluten.

flour (cake).notes: Essentially the same as the main 'cake flour' substitution.

flour (self-rising).notes: For 1 cup self-rising, combine 1 cup AP flour + 1.5 tsp baking powder + 0.5 tsp salt.

garam masala.notes: For ~1 tsp, use 3/4 tsp cumin + 1/4 tsp allspice or pie spice.

gelatin.notes: For 1 Tbsp gelatin, use ~1 Tbsp agar agar (may need slight adjustments).

ginger (fresh).notes: Use ~1/2 tsp ground per 1 Tbsp minced fresh.

ginger (dry).notes: Use about 2 tsp fresh for 1 tsp dried.

green onion.notes: Use 1:1 volume for a milder onion flavor.

herbs (fresh).notes: Use ~1 tsp dried for 1 Tbsp fresh (3:1 ratio).

honey.notes: Use equal amount; flavor changes slightly.
Use equal amount. Less complex flavor.
For 1 cup honey, use ~1 1/4 cup sugar + 1/3 cup water; adjust recipe liquids.

hot pepper sauce (e.g. Tabasco).notes: For 1 tsp sauce, use ~3/4 tsp cayenne + 1 tsp vinegar.

lard.notes: Use 1:1. Slightly different texture in baked goods.
Use ~7/8 cup oil for 1 cup lard.
1 cup lard ≈ 1 cup butter, but final product may be richer.

lemon grass.notes: Use ~1 Tbsp zest for 2 stalks lemongrass. Flavor is less herbal.

lemon juice.notes: Use equal amount, flavor changes slightly.
Use 1:1 in dressings or marinades; flavor differs.

lemon zest.notes: For 1 tsp zest, use ~1/2 tsp extract.
For 1 tsp zest, use 2 tsp juice; reduce other liquids slightly.

macadamia nuts.notes: Use equal amount, different flavor/texture but still crunchy.

mace.notes: Use equal amount; very similar flavor (mace is from nutmeg husk).

margarine.notes: For 1 cup margarine, use 1 cup shortening + 1/2 tsp salt if recipe needs salted butter taste.
Use equal amount. Flavor is richer.
7/8 cup oil + 1/2 tsp salt for 1 cup margarine.

marjoram.notes: Use about half the amount if dried oregano; flavor is stronger.
Similar mild sweetness; adjust to taste.

marsala wine.notes: Use equal amount. Flavor differs but close in sweetness.
Splash of brandy with white wine for depth.

milk.ingredientName: almond, soy, oat, or coconut milk
milk.notes: Use equal amount. Flavor changes slightly.
For some savory dishes. May affect richness.
Combine to approximate regular milk consistency.
Use equal volume, but thin with water to reach milk-like consistency.

mint (fresh).notes: Use about 1 Tbsp fresh = 1 tsp dried.

molasses.notes: Use equal amount; flavor will be lighter.
For 1 cup molasses, use ~3/4 cup brown sugar + 1/4 cup hot water.

mustard (prepared).notes: For 1 Tbsp prepared, combine 1 Tbsp dry mustard, 1 tsp water, 1 tsp vinegar, 1 tsp sugar.

nutmeg.notes: Use equal amount; nearly identical in flavor.
Use half the amount if strong flavors are undesirable.

onion.notes: Use ~1 cup green onion/shallots for 1 cup chopped onion.

onion.ingredientName: dried minced onion or onion powder
onion.notes: For 1 cup fresh onion, ~1/4 cup dried or 1/4 the volume onion powder.

orange juice.notes: Use equal amount (e.g., lemon/lime juice), flavor changes.

orange zest.notes: For 1 Tbsp zest, use ~1/2 tsp extract.
Use 1 tsp juice for 1 Tbsp zest; different flavor but still citrus.

oyster sauce.notes: Use equal amount. Less thick, add a bit of cornstarch if needed.
Sweeter, but has a similar thick consistency.

paprika.notes: Use equal or slightly more if you want extra heat.

parmesan cheese.notes: Use equal amount, flavor somewhat sharper.
Similar to Parmesan but sharper. Use equal amount.

parsley.notes: Use equal amount fresh. Lighter, more anise flavor.
Different flavor profiles, but can stand in for freshness.

peanut butter.notes: Use equal amount; allergen-friendly for peanut-free households.

peanut butter.ingredientName: almond butter or other nut butters

red wine vinegar.notes: Use equal amount; flavor is milder.
Stronger acidity, use slightly less if worried about harsh flavor.

rice vinegar.ingredientName: apple cider vinegar + small amount sugar
rice vinegar.notes: For 1 Tbsp rice vinegar, use 1 Tbsp cider vinegar + 1/2 tsp sugar.

rosemary.notes: Use about equal or slightly more thyme. Flavor differs but still earthy.

rum.notes: For 1 Tbsp rum, use ~1/2 tsp extract + enough water to make 1 Tbsp.

saffron.notes: Use equal amount for color, but flavor is different.

salami.notes: Use equal amount, flavor is spicier.

self-rising flour.notes: For 1 cup, use 1 cup AP flour + 1.5 tsp baking powder + 0.5 tsp salt.

sesame oil.notes: Use equal amount; flavor differs but also nutty.
Toast sesame seeds in neutral oil, strain. Approximate flavor.

shallots.notes: Use equal volume. Flavor is harsher.
Use equal volume, milder or more delicate.

shortening.notes: Use equal amount; adjust salt if needed.
Use equal amount; solid at room temp, similar to shortening.

sour cream.notes: Use equal amount. Flavor slightly tangier.

sour cream.ingredientName: 1 Tbsp lemon juice or vinegar + cream
sour cream.notes: For 1 cup sour cream, combine cream + acid; may need to thicken.
3/4 cup buttermilk + 1/3 cup butter for 1 cup sour cream.

sour milk.notes: For 1 cup, stir 1 Tbsp acid into enough milk to make 1 cup, let stand 5 min.

soy sauce.notes: For ~1/2 cup soy sauce, use 1/4 cup Worcestershire + 1 Tbsp water.

stock (beef or chicken).notes: Use 1 cube per cup of water.

sugar (white).notes: Use equal amount; adds moisture and a slight molasses flavor.
Use ~1 1/4 cups powdered for 1 cup sugar; may affect texture.
Use ~3/4 cup for 1 cup sugar; reduce other liquids slightly.
Use ~3/4 cup for 1 cup sugar; adjust liquid accordingly.

sweetened condensed milk.notes: For a 14 oz can, combine ~3/4 cup sugar + 1/2 cup water + 1 1/8 cups dry milk; simmer until thick.

table salt.notes: For 1/2 tsp table salt, use ~3/4 tsp kosher salt.

tarragon.notes: Use equal amount fresh; flavor is somewhat similar (mild licorice).
Use ~2x fresh basil for the same herbal intensity.

thyme.notes: Use equal or slightly more; adjust to taste. Flavor differences are subtle but distinct.
Use less, as rosemary is stronger.

tomato paste.ingredientName: simmered tomato sauce or pureed tomatoes
tomato paste.notes: Cook down until thick to concentrate flavor.
Inverse substitution if you’re out of sauce but have paste.

tomato sauce.notes: Use equal amount; flavor is fresh but may need seasoning.

vanilla extract.notes: Use equal amount; adds mild sweetness, less vanilla aroma.
Use equal amount. Adds a boozy aroma; might not be kid-friendly.

vegetable oil.ingredientName: canola oil, olive oil, or avocado oil
vegetable oil.notes: Use equal amount. Flavor changes with olive oil (stronger).
Use equal amount; slight coconut flavor, solidifies if cool.
Use equal amount for frying or sautéing; different flavor.

vegetable shortening.notes: Use 1:1. May affect texture slightly (but butter adds flavor).
Use equal amount; solid at room temp, good for crusts.

vinegar.notes: Use equal amount in marinades or baking. Flavor changes slightly.
Use equal amount for mild acidity.

white sugar.notes: Use equal amount; adds mild molasses flavor.
Use ~3/4 cup for 1 cup sugar; reduce other liquid slightly.
Use ~3/4 cup for 1 cup sugar; adjust liquids.
Texture is coarser; dissolve well or grind if needed.

wine (white or red).notes: Use equal amount; flavor changes, less acidity.
For dryness/acidity. 1 cup water + 1 Tbsp lemon/vinegar.
1 cup juice with 2 tsp vinegar approximates wine sweetness/acidity.

worcestershire sauce.ingredientName: soy sauce + lemon juice + sugar + hot sauce
worcestershire sauce.notes: For 1 Tbsp, combine ~2 tsp soy sauce, 1/4 tsp lemon juice, pinch sugar, dash hot sauce.

xanthan gum.ingredientName: chia seeds or ground flax + hot water
xanthan gum.notes: For 1 Tbsp xanthan gum, use 2.5 tsp hot water + 0.5 tsp chia or ground flax; let sit until thick.

yeast (active dry).notes: 1 (.25-oz) pkg active dry ≈ 1 cake compressed yeast.
Use equal measure (~2.25 tsp) but adjust rising times if needed.

yogurt.notes: Use equal amount; slightly different tang.
Similar tang and consistency. Greek yogurt is thicker.
